Introduction

Rubella is a vaccine-preventable viral illness caused by the rubella virus.  Patients develop a generalized maculopapular rash, often accompanied by mild fever and lymphadenopathy.  Rubella is generally self-limited; however, neonates with congenital rubella infection are at risk for significant morbidity and mortality.

Pathogenesis



The rubella virus is transmitted via respiratory droplets.  The virus adheres to and replicates within the nasopharynx and regional lymph nodes, and viremia occurs 5-7 days later, disseminating the virus to various tissues.  Viral shedding occurs 1 week before and 2 weeks after the rash, which appears with the formation of neutralizing antibodies.



Because the vaccine is highly effective, being unimmunized is the primary risk factor for infection.  Similarly, living in a geographic area with low vaccination rates is also a risk factor.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of rubella varies, depending on the patient's age at the time of infection:



  • Children:  Postnatal rubella infection typically causes a generalized maculopapular rash that lasts <3 days.  The rash is generally nontender and nonpruritic, although patients may report occasional, mild pruritus.  The rash typically begins on the face and spreads cephalocaudally within 24 hours, sparing the palms and soles.  Some patients also develop petechiae known as Forchheimer spots on the soft palate.  The rash may be preceded or accompanied by mild systemic symptoms, including low fever and lymphadenopathy involving the suboccipital, posterior articular, and posterior cervical nodes.
  • Adolescents and adults:  Rubella in adolescents and adults presents similarly to that in children.  These patients have postnatal infection, although the rash may last longer.  Primary infection in adult women often causes arthralgia and arthritis involving the knees, wrists, and fingers that can persist for >1 month.

Diagnosis



Diagnostic testing should be performed in cases of suspected rubella (eg, nonimmune patient with acute onset of a generalized maculopapular rash and potential exposure to the virus).  Rubella-specific IgM serology is the initial diagnostic test.  If IgM is initially negative, repeat testing should be performed 2-4 weeks later in highly suspicious cases.  Real-time reverse transcriptaseâ€“PCR may be performed, but results are most accurate when the specimen is obtained within 3 days of rash onset.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for rubella includes other types of infectious exanthems, such as:



  • Measles (
    figure 1
    ):  Measles presents with a maculopapular rash that can also spread cephalocaudally.  After a few days, the rash coalesces and darkens.  Patients are generally ill-appearing with high fever, cough, and coryza.
  • Parvovirus B19 infection (
    image 1
    ):  This virus can cause erythema infectiosum, which presents with prodromal symptoms (eg, fever, rhinorrhea) followed by an erythematous malar rash (ie, slapped cheeks) and a reticular rash on the body.  The rash typically does not appear until prodromal symptoms have resolved.  In addition, palatal lesions (eg, Forchheimer spots) and posterior auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy are not typical.
  • Scarlet fever:  Presenting with fever, palatal petechiae, and a fine papular rash, scarlet fever is due to streptococcal infection.  The rash usually begins and is most prominent along skinfolds (eg, axillae, groin) and then spreads to the trunk and extremities.
  • Roseola:  Caused by human herpesvirus 6, roseola causes high fever followed by a diffuse, maculopapular rash that appears as the fever subsides.

Management and prognosis



The management of rubella is supportive, including antipyretics, analgesics, and hydration.  The course of illness is generally self-limited with a favorable prognosis.  Most patients recover completely, although reinfection can occur.  All confirmed cases of rubella should be reported to the local health department for detection of potential outbreaks.

Special consideration: congenital rubella syndrome



Congenital rubella infection (transplacental transmission of the virus from mother to fetus) can lead to a spectrum of clinical outcomes, ranging from miscarriage to congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) with varying severity (

).  In addition to nonspecific findings of congenital infection (eg, symmetric growth restriction, hepatosplenomegaly), early manifestations of CRS include:



  • Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss
  • Congenital heart disease (eg, patent ductus arteriosus, peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis)
  • Ocular involvement (eg, cataracts, glaucoma, pigmented retinopathy)
  • CNS involvement (eg, microcephaly, meningoencephalitis).
  • Purpuric lesions (nonblanching blue/purple nodules) described as a blueberry muffin rash


Infection during the first trimester is particularly threatening and results in the most severe phenotypes because it occurs during organogenesis, and the mother is often asymptomatic.  The diagnosis is confirmed with rubella-specific IgM serology, PCR, or viral culture using specimens from neonates.

Prevention



In general, rubella is a self-limited viral illness with a favorable prognosis.  However, the virus is particularly threatening to fetuses and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality.  Therefore, the goal of rubella vaccination is to prevent congenital rubella syndrome.  The rubella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine available only as part of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.  The vaccine is highly effective with a seroconversion rate of approximately 95% after a single dose.  Vaccination is the best method for preventing congenital rubella syndrome.  The vaccine should be given prior to conception; because it is a live virus, MMR is contraindicated during pregnancy.  All pregnant women are screened for immunity (ie, rubella-specific IgG serology), and all nonimmune women should be vaccinated postpartum.



Because the rubella virus can be spread via droplets, proper precautions should be taken to avoid further spread, especially to those who may be pregnant.

Summary



Rubella (
